title: 110_hr3050
content: The consent of Congress is given to an interstate forest fire protection compact known as "THE GREAT PLAINS WILDLAND FIRE PROTECTION AGREEMENT" between State, Provincial, and Territorial wildland fire protection agencies. The Great Plains Wildland Fire Protection Agreement aims to prevent and control forest fires in the region by maintaining fire fighting services and providing reciprocal aid among member states like South Dakota, North Dakota, Wyoming, and Colorado. The compact becomes effective once ratified by two or more member states. The Great Plains Wildland Fire Protection Agreement allows state foresters to act as compact administrators, coordinating forest fire prevention and control efforts among member states. Each state can develop and implement a forest fire plan. "ARTICLE IV states that if a state forest fire control agency requests aid from another member state, the requested state may provide assistance while ensuring protection at home. ARTICLE V is not provided." If a member state provides aid to another state under the compact, the employees rendering aid will have the same powers, duties, and immunities as comparable employees of the receiving state. The providing state and its employees are not liable for any actions or maintenance related to the aid provided. The compact states that employees rendering aid will have the same powers, duties, and immunities as comparable employees of the receiving state. Liability for any actions or maintenance related to the aid provided is assumed and borne by the requesting state. The compact states that liability for any actions or maintenance related to the aid provided shall be assumed and borne by the requesting state. Any member state rendering aid shall be reimbursed for expenses incurred in the operation of equipment and other costs. The compact states that the requesting state will reimburse any member state for expenses incurred in providing aid, including equipment operation, materials, transportation, wages, and maintenance. The assisting state may also assume these costs or provide aid without charge. Each member state must ensure workers' compensation benefits. The compact allows assisting member states to assume costs or provide aid without charge. Each member state must ensure workers' compensation benefits for employees and contract firefighters sent to a requesting state. The compact ensures workers' compensation benefits for employees and contract firefighters sent to a requesting state, including volunteers and auxiliary members. Compact administrators may establish procedures for claims and reimbursement in accordance with state laws. "ARTICLE VI outlines the procedures for claims and reimbursement of workers' compensation benefits for employees and contract firefighters under the compact." "Ratification of this compact does not authorize any member state to reduce its forest fire fighting forces, equipment, services, or facilities. Each state must maintain adequate resources for forest fire protection as if the compact were not in effect. The compact does not limit a state's power to prevent and control forest fires." The compact does not limit a state's power to prevent, control, and extinguish forest fires, and does not affect any existing or future cooperative relationships between the United States. The compact allows states to prevent, control, and extinguish forest fires without affecting their cooperative relationships with the United States Forest Service. "Representatives of the United States Forest Service may attend meetings of the compact administrators. The provisions of Articles IV and V of this compact regarding reciprocal aid in combating forest fires apply between states party to this compact and other states that have given assent to mutual aid provisions." The compact remains binding until a state takes action to withdraw, which becomes effective six months after notice is sent to all states.
